Class OperationsManager

java.lang.Object
OperationsManager
public class OperationsManager extends Object
This is a class that manages operations and what to do should an operation button be pressed using if statements. This includes the four basic operations as well as root, power, sin, cos, tan, 1/x, converting to percent, switching between plus and minus, absolute value, log, clear and equals.
Version:
7/4/2024
Author:
Jeremy D. W.

    • divide

      public void divide(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the division button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the division button at the same time by running the methods to check the calculations.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • add

      public void add(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the add button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the add button at the same time by running the methods to check the calculations.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • multipy

      public void multipy(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the multiply button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the multiply button at the same time by running the methods to check the calculations.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

      public void subtract(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the subtract button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the subtract button at the same time by running the methods to check the calculations.

    • power

      public void power(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the power button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the power button at the same time by running themethods to check the calculations.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • root

      public void root(JTextArea display)
      This is the logic for the root button, aside from what booleans are triggered, it's the same as the other 5, two-input style operators. It uses the checkEmpty() method to make sure nothing is done should the display be empty or just a decimal (period) is in the display. Then, if there is a non-zero value in temp, it treats the button like the equals button and the root button at the same time by running the applyCalculations method.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • percent

      public void percent(JTextArea display)
      Checks if the display is empty or has just a decimal (period), if not, sets the text in the JTextArea to what it was divided by 100.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • plusMinus

      public void plusMinus(JTextArea display)
      Checks if the display is empty or has just a decimal (period), if not, sets the text in the JTextArea to what it was multiplied by -1.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • checkEmpty

      public boolean checkEmpty(JTextArea display)
      Checks if a JTextArea is completely empty or only has a decimal (period) using the getText and equals methods and returns a corresponding true or false value.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that has it's text checked.
      Returns:
      a true or false value depending on if the JTextArea is empty/only contains a decimal (period) or contains something.

    • equal

      public void equal(JTextArea display)
      Runs the applyCalculations method and then sets every boolean in this class to false; it's exactly as you would expect from a standard calculator.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that numbers are taken from and displayed to.

    • clear

      public void clear(JTextArea display)
      Sets every boolean to false, temp to zero and sets the text of the JTextArea to nothing; it's exactly as you would expect from a real calculator.
      Parameters:
      display - the JTextArea that has its text set to nothing.

    • setCleared

      public void setCleared(boolean c)
      Sets the cleared variable to that of the user's choosing.
      Parameters:
      c - the value that cleared is to beset to.

    • getCleared

      public boolean getCleared()
      Returns the value of the cleared variable.
      Returns:
      the cleared variable, used to check if the JTextArea has been cleared so that I user can enter more than one number after hitting an operator button.
